Steps to reproduce
------------------

```
Follow the "Installation via Package Repository - Ubuntu 14.04" instructions (https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/installation/linux.md#installation-via-package-repository---ubuntu-1404)
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

``` 

# Install PowerShell
sudo apt-get install -y powershell
...(apt-get finds package package powershell and installs)...

```

Actual behavior
---------------

```
# Install PowerShell
sudo apt-get install -y powershell
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree
Reading state information... Done
E: Unable to locate package powershell

```

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```

>lsb_release -a
Distributor ID: Ubuntu
Description:    Ubuntu 14.04.5 LTS
Release:        14.04
Codename:       trusty

>uname -a
Linux 4.4.0-116-generic #140~14.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Fri Feb 16 09:25:49 UTC 2018 i686 i686 i686 GNU/Linux

>sudo apt-key list
...
pub   2048R/BE1229CF 2015-10-28
uid                  Microsoft (Release signing) <gpgsecurity@microsoft.com>
...

>sudo apt-get update |grep microsoft
Hit https://packages.microsoft.com trusty InRelease
Hit https://packages.microsoft.com trusty/main amd64 Packages
Get:1 https://packages.microsoft.com trusty/main Translation-en_US
Ign https://packages.microsoft.com trusty/main Translation-en_US
Ign https://packages.microsoft.com trusty/main Translation-en
```

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body:
I just verified that these instruction work:  https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-Docs/blob/staging/reference/docs-conceptual/setup/Installing-PowerShell-Core-on-macOS-and-Linux.md#installation-via-package-repository---ubuntu-1404 

I specifically ran the following (steps 1 and 2 are needed because I used a docker container):

1. `apt update` # getting ready to install dependencies, not in **docker** image
2.  `apt install apt-utils ca-certificates curl apt-transport-https sudo` # installing dependencies not in **docker** image.
4.  `curl https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc | sudo apt-key add -`
6.  `curl https://packages.microsoft.com/config/ubuntu/14.04/prod.list | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/microsoft.list`
8.  `sudo apt-get update`
10.  `sudo apt-get install -y powershell`

comments.author: DwightGappa
comments.body:
I apologize, I forgot to specifically mention that I running am I running 32bit (i386) Ubuntu 14.04. It is in the 'uname -a' (kernel version output) but didn't explicitly call that out. 

> uname -a
>Linux 4.4.0-116-generic #140~14.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Fri Feb 16 09:25:49 UTC 2018 ****i686 i686 i686**** GNU/Linux

I tried it again today and still didn't work. I figured out the issue why it is not working after looking at the manual install instructions because the package is a 64bit package. A 64bit package will never install on a 32bit system

I copied this from the manual download steps from the install instructions to point out that this a 64bit (amd64) package.

> Download the Debian package powershell_6.0.2-1.ubuntu.14.04_****amd64****.deb from the releases page onto the Ubuntu machine. 

Now I have looked to that are no 32bit (i386) builds of Powershell for Linux.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: We don't have a 32-bit i386 package or build.  I'm going to close this and can you file a new issue that asks for a new feature supporting `i386`

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: Perhaps `ca-certificates` should be added to our package, but it's not a direct dependency.  The other two packages are required for setup of the package and therefore there is no use adding them to the package.

title: Ubuntu 14.04 Installation via Package Repository Fails apt-get "E: Unable to locate package powershell"
